conclusion: A coordinate system with V (volume) on the vertical axis and T (temperature) on the horizontal axis
Point A is at coordinates (T₀, V₀)
Point C is at the origin (0, 0)
The line BC, when extended, passes through the origin
AB is parallel to the V-axis (horizontal line)
The gas changes from state A to state B along a horizontal line, indicating an isothermal process at temperature T₀
Given information: Pressure at point A: pₐ = p₀, Temperature at point A: Tₐ = T₀
Since points A and B lie on the same isotherm (T = T₀), and this is an ideal gas, pV = constant, leading to pₐVₐ = pᵦVᵦ
We know that Vᵦ = 2V₀, Vₐ = V₀, pₐ = p₀
p₀ × V₀ = pᵦ × 2V₀, therefore pᵦ = p₀/2
The pressure at point B is half the pressure at point A
For an ideal gas, the first law of thermodynamics states: Q = ΔU + W
For an isothermal process in an ideal gas, the internal energy depends only on temperature, so ΔU = 0
The heat absorbed by the gas during the process from state A to state B is 10 J
In an isothermal process for an ideal gas, all the heat added to the system is converted to work done by the gas
